author: MIKE GRIFFITH
title: HOCKEY: Reign opens first AHL season with 5-0 win over Condors
text:
By MIKE GRIFFITH / CONTRIBUTING WRITER
Published: Oct. 10, 2015 Updated: 10:47 p.m. BAKERSFIELD – The American Hockey League’s defending champions opened the season on Saturday night with a new name, in a new road city and with a pair of NHL veterans in the lineup.
The Ontario Reign, the 2015-16 version of the Manchester Monarchs after the big move West by the AHL this summer, picked up where they left off a few months ago on the other coast with a 5-0 victory over the Bakersfield Condors.
With goaltender Patrik Bartosak, who helped lead the Monarchs to the title last season, injured and Michael Houser apparently not yet ready for prime time, the Reign added a pair of veteran National Hockey League goaltenders to the roster on Saturday.
Peter Budaj (296 regular-season games in nine seasons in the NHL) signed a one-year contract with the LA Kings on Friday and started in net on Saturday after being assigned to the Reign.
Budaj was barely tested as he stopped 21 shots.
Watching from the bench was 13-year NHL vet Ray Emery, who signed a Professional Tryout Agreement with the Reign on Saturday. Emery (287 NHL games) stood out in a sea of black as he played for Philadelphia Flyers the past two seasons and still had the white-and orange pads, blocker and glove.
But this one wasn’t about the goaltenders.
It was about total domination in all areas of the game by the Reign, who return 15 players from that championship team.
The Edmonton Oilers-affiliated Condors had no answer for the Reign anywhere on the ice. Reign players seemed to block shots at will and forced numerous turnovers throughout the game.
Vincent LoVerde, who started his pro career with Ontario in the ECHL in 2011, staked the Reign to a 1-0 lead nine minutes into the first when his shot from the right point sailed through traffic and past Laurent Brossoit.
Scott Saborin scored on a follow-up shot off an odd-man rush with two minutes left in the period for a 2-0 lead.
The Reign put the game away in the second.
Kris Newbury scored an easy goal off a turnover at 10:20, and got a power-play goal at 13:48, and Paul Bissonnette, known more for penalty minutes than goals, scored off a turnover at 14:48.
